Title: Accessibility
Description: Accessibility in Froala Editor ensures that all users, including those with disabilities, can effectively interact with the editor, promoting inclusivity in content creation.

Title: API
Description: The API provides a set of methods and endpoints for developers to interact programmatically with the Froala Editor, enabling customization and integration.

Title: ARIA
Description: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) is a set of attributes that enhance the accessibility of web applications, ensuring that users with disabilities can interact with the Froala Editor effectively.

Title: Buttons
Description: Buttons in the Froala WYSIWYG Editor are customizable elements that enhance user interaction by providing quick access to various editing functions. They streamline the editing process and improve productivity by allowing users to perform actions with a single click.

Title: Character Counter
Description: The character counter feature tracks the number of characters typed in the editor, helping users manage content length and comply with limits.

Title: charCounterMax
Description: charCounterMax is a feature in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor that limits the number of characters a user can input. It enhances user experience by providing real-time character counting and prevents exceeding the defined limit, ensuring content remains concise and manageable.

Title: Code View
Description: Code View is a mode in the Froala Editor that allows users to directly edit the HTML source code of their content, providing full control over the markup.

Title: Codox
Description: Codox is a powerful WYSIWYG HTML editor designed for ease of use and integration into various applications. It enhances productivity by allowing real-time collaboration and offers extensive features for formatting and content management.

Title: Content Formats
Description: Content formats refer to the various types of data that can be created and manipulated within the Froala Editor, including HTML, Markdown, and plain text.

Title: Content Management System (CMS)
Description: A CMS is a software application that enables users to create, manage, and modify content on a website without needing specialized technical knowledge.

Title: Content Manipulation
Description: Content manipulation refers to the various operations that can be performed on the editor's content, such as inserting, deleting, or modifying elements.

Title: Content Methods
Description: Content Methods are a set of API functions provided by the Froala Editor that allow developers to manipulate and retrieve content within the editor programmatically.

Title: Content Sanitization
Description: Content sanitization in Froala Editor ensures that user-generated content is cleaned and safe from malicious code, protecting applications from security vulnerabilities.

Title: Copy/Paste
Description: The copy/paste feature allows users to easily duplicate and transfer content within the Froala Editor, enhancing productivity and content management.

Title: Cross-Browser Compatibility
Description: Cross-browser compatibility ensures that the Froala Editor functions consistently across different web browsers, providing a uniform user experience.

Title: CSS
Description: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML. It enhances the visual appearance of web pages, allowing for layout, colors, fonts, and overall design, making it essential for web development.

Title: Custom Button
Description: A Custom Button in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor allows users to create personalized buttons for specific commands, enhancing the editor's functionality and user experience by enabling tailored interactions.

Title: Design Blocks
Description: Design Blocks are modular components within the Froala WYSIWYG Editor that allow users to create and customize content layouts easily. They enhance productivity by providing pre-defined structures that can be quickly inserted and modified.

Title: Design Builder
Description: Design Builder is a powerful tool that enables users to create and customize web pages visually without needing extensive coding knowledge. It streamlines the design process, making it accessible to both developers and non-developers.

Title: Document Mode
Description: Document Mode in Froala WYSIWYG Editor allows users to create and manage online documents efficiently. It simplifies document creation and enhances user productivity by providing a rich text editing experience tailored for document management systems.

Title: DOM
Description: The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for web documents that represents the structure of a document as a tree of objects. It allows developers to manipulate the content, structure, and style of web pages dynamically, making it essential for interactive web applications.

Title: Dropdowns
Description: Dropdowns are UI elements that allow users to select an option from a list. They enhance user experience by saving space and providing a cleaner interface, making it easier to navigate through options.

Title: Edit-in-Popup
Description: Edit-in-Popup is a mode in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor that allows users to edit content in a popup window, enhancing the editing experience by providing a focused interface. This feature is essential for maintaining a clean workspace while editing.

Title: Editor Instance
Description: An editor instance refers to a specific instance of the Froala Editor that is initialized on a DOM element, allowing for unique configurations and content management.

Title: Emoticons
Description: The emoticons plugin allows users to insert emoticons into their content, enhancing expression and engagement in text-based communication.

Title: Event Methods
Description: Event methods are a collection of API functions that allow developers to manage and respond to events occurring within the Froala Editor, enabling dynamic user interactions.

Title: Events System
Description: The Events System in Froala Editor allows developers to listen for and respond to various actions and changes within the editor, enhancing interactivity and user experience.

Title: File Attachment
Description: File Attachment is a feature that allows users to attach files to their content within the Froala Editor, enhancing the richness of the content created.

Title: File Manager
Description: The File Manager is a crucial component of the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor, enabling users to easily browse, insert, and manage files such as images and documents directly within the editor interface, enhancing productivity and content management.

Title: File Upload
Description: File Upload refers to the capability of the Froala Editor to handle file uploads, allowing users to insert files into their content seamlessly. It is crucial for applications requiring document management.

Title: Formatting
Description: Formatting in the Froala Editor encompasses the various ways users can style text and content, including font styles, colors, and alignment.

Title: Framework Integration
Description: Framework integration in Froala Editor allows seamless incorporation into various development frameworks, enhancing versatility and usability for developers.

Title: Frontend Development
Description: Frontend Development refers to the practice of building the user interface and user experience of web applications, including the integration of the Froala Editor into web pages.

Title: Fullscreen Mode
Description: Fullscreen mode expands the editor to occupy the entire screen, providing a distraction-free environment for content creation.

Title: getHTML
Description: The getHTML function in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor allows users to retrieve the current HTML content of the editor. This is essential for saving or processing the content created by users, making it a critical feature for any application utilizing the editor.

Title: HTML
Description: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for creating web pages. It structures web content and is essential for web development, enabling the display of text, images, and other media in browsers.

Title: HTML Content
Description: HTML Content refers to the structured markup language used for creating web pages. It is essential for defining the layout, structure, and presentation of web content, making it a cornerstone of web development.

Title: HTML Validation
Description: HTML Validation is the process of checking HTML code for compliance with web standards. It ensures that the markup is correct, which helps improve accessibility, SEO, and overall user experience.

Title: HTMLAllowedTags
Description: HTMLAllowedTags refers to the specific HTML tags that are permitted within the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor. This feature is crucial for ensuring that only safe and relevant HTML is used, which helps maintain the integrity and security of the content being edited.

Title: HyperText Markup Language
Description: HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is the standard markup language for creating web pages. It structures content on the web and is essential for web development, enabling the display of text, images, and other media in browsers.

Title: Iframe Mode
Description: Iframe Mode allows the WYSIWYG HTML editor's content to be isolated from the rest of the page, preventing any style or script conflicts. This is crucial for maintaining a clean and consistent editing environment.

Title: Ignition DiscountFroala Editor
Description: Ignition DiscountFroala Editor is a powerful WYSIWYG HTML text editor that enhances content creation through its rich features, including real-time collaboration, advanced formatting, and seamless integration with various applications, making it essential for developers and users alike.

Title: Image Management
Description: Image Management refers to the capabilities within the Froala Editor that allow users to upload, organize, and manipulate images effectively within their content.

Title: Image Manager
Description: The Image Manager is a plugin that enables users to manage and organize images within the Froala Editor, allowing for easy browsing and deletion of images stored on the server.

Title: Image Upload
Description: Image Upload is a feature that allows users to upload images directly into the Froala Editor, enhancing content creation with visual elements. This is essential for rich media applications.

Title: image.beforeUpload
Description: The image.beforeUpload event is triggered before an image is uploaded in the Froala WYSIWYG Editor. It allows developers to implement custom logic, such as validation or modification of the image before the upload process begins, enhancing control over image handling.

Title: image.error
Description: The 'image.error' refers to the handling of errors related to image processing within the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor. It is crucial for maintaining a smooth user experience by providing feedback when image uploads fail or when images cannot be displayed.

Title: image.inserted
Description: The 'image.inserted' event in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor signifies that an image has been successfully added to the content. This event is crucial for triggering any follow-up actions, such as updating the user interface or saving changes, ensuring a seamless editing experience.

Title: image.uploaded
Description: The 'image.uploaded' feature in Froala's WYSIWYG HTML editor allows users to seamlessly upload and manage images within their content. This capability enhances the editing experience by enabling rich media integration, which is crucial for creating visually appealing documents.

Title: Initialization
Description: Initialization refers to the process of setting up the WYSIWYG editor, configuring its settings, and preparing it for use.

Title: initialized
Description: Initialization refers to the process of setting up the WYSIWYG HTML editor on a specific HTML element, allowing it to become interactive and functional. This is crucial for enabling rich text editing capabilities in web applications.

Title: initOnClick
Description: initOnClick is a feature that enhances page performance by initializing the WYSIWYG editor only when the user clicks in the editable area. This approach is particularly beneficial for pages with multiple rich text editors, as it reduces initial load time and resource usage.

Title: Inline Mode
Description: Inline mode in Froala Editor allows users to edit content directly within the page, providing a seamless and intuitive editing experience.

Title: Inline Styles
Description: Inline Styles allow users to apply custom styles directly to selected text, images, or links within the WYSIWYG HTML editor. This feature enhances the flexibility and visual appeal of content creation, enabling precise control over the appearance of elements.

Title: Input Filtering
Description: Input Filtering involves restricting the types of data that can be entered into the editor, enhancing security by preventing malicious content.

Title: Instance Object
Description: An Instance Object in the context of the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor refers to a specific instance of the editor that allows for rich text editing capabilities within applications. It is essential for enabling users to create and manipulate content dynamically.

Title: JavaScript
Description: JavaScript is a versatile programming language that enables interactive web pages and is an essential part of web applications. It allows developers to create dynamic content, control multimedia, and animate images, making it a critical tool for modern web development.

Title: Keyboard Navigation
Description: Keyboard navigation refers to the ability to navigate and operate the Froala Editor using keyboard shortcuts, enhancing accessibility for all users.

Title: Learning Management System (LMS)
Description: An LMS is a software application for the administration, documentation, tracking, reporting, and delivery of educational courses or training programs.

Title: Lifecycle
Description: The lifecycle of the Froala Editor encompasses the various stages from initialization to destruction, managing the editor's state and resources throughout its use.

Title: Lists
Description: The lists feature enables users to create ordered and unordered lists, enhancing content organization and readability.

Title: Markdown
Description: Markdown is a lightweight markup language that allows users to format text using simple syntax, making it easy to create rich content without complex HTML.

Title: Media Handling
Description: Media handling in Froala Editor allows users to embed and manage various media types, enhancing the richness of the content they create.

Title: Media Management
Description: Media management encompasses the tools and functionalities for handling various media types, including images, videos, and audio files within the editor.

Title: Modals
Description: Modals are interactive dialog boxes that overlay on the main content, allowing users to perform actions or view information without navigating away from the current page. They enhance user experience by providing focused interaction.

Title: Perpetual License
Description: A Perpetual License allows users to use software indefinitely after a one-time purchase. This model is significant as it provides long-term access without recurring fees, appealing to businesses seeking cost-effective solutions.

Title: Plugin Architecture
Description: Plugin Architecture in Froala WYSIWYG Editor allows developers to extend the editor's functionality by integrating third-party libraries and custom plugins, enhancing the editing experience and enabling tailored solutions for various applications.

Title: Plugins System
Description: The Plugins System in Froala Editor allows for the extension of core functionalities through additional plugins, enabling developers to customize the editor to meet specific needs.

Title: pluginsDisabled
Description: The 'pluginsDisabled' option in the Froala WYSIWYG Editor allows developers to disable specific plugins, providing greater control over the editor's functionality and ensuring a streamlined user experience. This is essential for customizing the editor to meet specific project requirements.

Title: pluginsEnabled
Description: The 'pluginsEnabled' setting in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML editor allows developers to activate specific plugins that enhance the editor's functionality. This modular approach enables customization, ensuring that only necessary features are included, which can improve performance and user experience.

Title: Popups
Description: Popups in the Froala WYSIWYG Editor enhance the user experience by providing intuitive interfaces for editing and interacting with content. They are designed to be modern and highly customizable, making editing seamless and efficient.

Title: Preview Mode
Description: Preview mode allows users to see how their content will appear once published, providing a way to verify formatting and layout.

Title: Quick Insert
Description: The Quick Insert feature in Froala Editor allows users to easily add frequently used elements, enhancing productivity and streamlining the editing process.

Title: Real-time Collaboration
Description: Real-time Collaboration allows multiple users to edit content simultaneously, providing a dynamic and interactive editing experience.

Title: Rich Text Editing
Description: Rich text editing allows users to format text with various styles and elements visually, without needing to write HTML code directly. This enhances user experience and content creation.

Title: Rich Text Editor
Description: A Rich Text Editor is a powerful tool that allows users to create and format content visually, without needing to write HTML code. It enhances productivity and user experience by providing intuitive editing capabilities.

Title: S3 Uploads
Description: S3 Uploads refer to the process of uploading files to Amazon S3 (Simple Storage Service), a scalable storage solution that allows for secure and reliable data storage. This capability is crucial for applications requiring efficient data management and accessibility.

Title: SaaS
Description: Software as a Service (SaaS) is a cloud-based service where instead of downloading software on your desktop PC or business network, you instead access an application via an internet browser. This model allows for easier updates, scalability, and accessibility from any device with internet connectivity.

Title: Screen Reader Support
Description: Screen reader support ensures that the Froala Editor is usable by individuals with visual impairments, providing auditory feedback for content editing.

Title: Section 508
Description: Section 508 is a part of the Rehabilitation Act that requires federal agencies to make their electronic and information technology accessible to people with disabilities. Compliance ensures equal access to information and technology for all users.

Title: Security Concepts
Description: Security concepts encompass the measures taken to protect the Froala Editor from vulnerabilities, such as XSS attacks and ensuring content sanitization.

Title: Selection Methods
Description: Selection methods provide API functions that enable developers to manage text selection within the Froala Editor, enhancing user interaction capabilities.

Title: SEO Friendly
Description: SEO-friendly features ensure that content created with the Froala Editor is optimized for search engines, enhancing visibility and ranking.

Title: Source Code
Description: Source code refers to the underlying HTML generated by the Froala Editor, allowing users to view and edit the raw markup of their content.

Title: Standard Mode
Description: Standard Mode in the Froala WYSIWYG Editor provides a full-featured editing experience that combines ease of use with powerful capabilities, making it ideal for users who require comprehensive text editing tools.

Title: Table Plugin
Description: The Table Plugin in the Froala WYSIWYG HTML Editor allows users to create and manage tables easily, providing essential features for organizing data effectively within the editor. This functionality enhances content structure and presentation.

Title: Tables
Description: The tables feature in Froala Editor allows users to create and manage tables easily, enhancing the organization and presentation of data within content.

Title: Toolbar
Description: The Toolbar is a critical UI component of the Froala Editor that provides users with access to various editing tools and features, enhancing the editing experience.

Title: Track Changes
Description: Track Changes allows users to monitor modifications made to text, images, and tables within the editor, highlighting additions and deletions. This feature is crucial for collaborative editing, ensuring clarity and accountability in document revisions.

Title: Undo/Redo
Description: Undo/Redo functionality allows users to revert or reapply changes made in the Froala Editor, enhancing the editing experience by providing control over content modifications.

Title: Video Embed
Description: Video Embed allows users to insert video content from various platforms directly into the editor, enhancing the multimedia experience of the content.

Title: WCAG 2.0
Description: WCAG 2.0 refers to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, which provide a framework for making web content more accessible to people with disabilities. Adhering to these guidelines ensures that digital content is usable by everyone, regardless of their abilities.

Title: WYSIWYG Editor
Description: A WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) editor allows users to create and edit content in a format that closely resembles the final output, making it intuitive for non-technical users.

Title: XSS Protection
Description: XSS Protection refers to the measures implemented in the Froala Editor to prevent cross-site scripting attacks, ensuring the security of user-generated content.
